title: Cori “Coco” Gauff, 15, wins first WTA title as stunning breakthrough season rolls on
text:
Cori Gauff won a first WTA title (Picture: APA/AFP via Getty)

Cori “Coco” Gauff’s remarkable breakthrough season continued as she defeated former French Open champion Jelena Ostapenko in Linz, becoming the youngest WTA title winner in 15 years.

Gauff, 15, was beaten in qualifying but entered the main draw as a lucky loser and has not looked back.

After claiming her first top-10 win against Kiki Bertens, reaching a first tour-level semi-final and final, as well as cracking the top-100 in a wonderful week in Austria, she downed Ostapenko 6-3 1-6 6-2 to win a first singles title of her embryonic career.

Ostapenko was beaten (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

One-time Grand Slam winner Ostapenko made things tough until a controversial call from the umpire early in the third set saw her broken and she ultimately fell away.

Gauff will rise just outside the top-70 when the WTA rankings are next released on Monday.

She said after the match: ‘I want to thank God for always supporting me like I wouldn’t be here without him. It’s been an amazing week and I hope to come back in the future.

‘I’ll definitely remember this moment for the rest of my life.’

She has enjoyed a stunning year, having become the youngest player to qualify at Wimbledon in the Open Era before storming to the fourth round, while also reaching the third round in her home Slam at the US Open. One suspects this won’t be her last professional title.

On the charcoal courts of Austria, the often streaky Ostapenko struggled to find her best form and Gauff accelerated into a one-set lead.

Cori Gauff’s dad gave her a rousing speech (Picture: APA/AFP via Getty Images)

The Latvian surged back in the second, striking with power and purpose to level things up.

In the second game of the decider, the umpire overruled a linesperson who called a Gauff stroke, which caught the baseline, out and controversially decided that it was a late call, which didn’t affect an Ostapenko backhand that sailed wide.

The decision saw Ostapenko broken and enraged, groaning: ‘Can you see the ball? Are you sure?’ She was handed a warning for her troubles.

Ostapenko’s head dropped and so did her game, with Gauff seemingly en route to a comfortable victory as she stormed into a 5-0 lead.

Cori Gauff came through (Picture: APA/AFP via Getty Images)

However, two championship points came and went, with Ostapenko avoiding the bagel and the Latvian secured one of the breaks back as nerves took hold of the 15-year-old so close to the finish line.

Her father was called to the court at the 5-2 changeover and told his daughter: ‘We’re not going to sprint to the finish line. We’re going to walk to it. If you had 5-2 this time yesterday you’d have taken it’.

To the finish line, she did ultimately arrive, and she broke at the next time of asking to win a first WTA title.
